{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3534083,"name":"Sam","username":"Paraduks","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/ea5d25/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T14:34:06.163Z","cooked":"

Hi all,
I have been attempting to simulate our robot code and, after I realized we were hitting Loop Overruns by calling .configure() on a SparkMax object every update cycle, I switched all our usages of .configure() to .configureAsync(). This fixes loop overruns when we are connected to the robot…but when I try to simulate the code on my windows computer it crashes, with a “A fatal error has been detected by the Java Runtime Environment…” memory error message. Here is the current implementation that causes the error:

public static void configureMotor(SparkMax motor, SparkMaxConfig config) {
    motor.configureAsync(config, ResetMode.kResetSafeParameters, PersistMode.kPersistParameters);
}

I can only guess that there may be a bug in the Rev 2025 library. Has anyone else encountered this issue, and does anyone know possible workarounds?

If it’s a sim only crash, a simple workaround might be to call the non-async function in sim and the async function on the real robot. This can be done in your code by checking the result of RobotBase.isSimulation().

Paraduks:

calling .configure() on a SparkMax object every update cycle

You probably do not want to do this, even with the async flavor – it could drive your CAN utilization way up. Think about what you really want to achieve and try to do it in a way that minimizes activity that involves the configure side of things. Ideally, you config once (maybe in one of the init methods) and then only reapply if the controller reboots or there is some other unusual condition.

It’s possible REVLib now filters things so it only sends CAN messages when they are needed, but even then you would be calling something that’s doing a fair amount of computation for no reason.
